Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was halfway through trimming Mrs. Lee’s fringe when my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Don’t forget to vote before 5 PM!” She smiled at me in the mirror, her eyes crinkling. “Could you just take a little more off the left side?” she asked, as she always did. I nodded, knowing how much she valued these small adjustments. My mind, though, was already at the polling station, replaying the instructions the election official had given me earlier. I’d signed my ballot envelope, but the ink had smudged. The poll worker had asked me to re-sign it, stressing how important it was for my vote to count. I remembered the seriousness in their voice, the line of people waiting behind me, and my own anxiety about doing everything right. Now, with scissors in hand, I felt torn—Mrs. Lee expected my full attention and care, but the weight of civic duty pressed on me. I could feel my heart race as I tried to focus on her hair, wondering if I should excuse myself to fix my ballot or stay and finish the job she trusted me with.
